A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an p-group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To understand whether the concept of a set is necessary for the definition of a p-group, we need to analyze the components of the definition of a p-group. A p-group is defined as a finite group G where the order of G (the number of elements in G) is a power of a prime number p. A group, in the context of mathematics, is a set equipped with an operation that satisfies certain axioms (closure, associativity, identity element, and inverses). Therefore, the concept of a group inherently relies on the concept of a set, as a group is a specific type of set with additional structure. Since a p-group is a type of group, the definition of a p-group presupposes the existence of a set (the group itself). Without the concept of a set, the notion of a group, and consequently a p-group, would not be meaningful or definable. Thus, the concept of a set is necessary for the definition of a p-group to make sense.
